image.altText: an aboriginal couple with a little baby

items.synopsis: A Northern Territory family with a one-month-old baby say they have spent weeks living in a public house overrun with sewage, despite repeated calls for help.

title.children: Remote NT family fear baby will fall ill due to 'disgusting' housing conditions

image.altText: Smoke is coming from Gaza following Israeli strikes.

items.synopsis: Hamas says Israel’s heavy bombardment of the Gaza Strip has killed 13 hostages, including foreigners, held by the group. Follow live

title.children: Thirteen hostages, including foreigners, killed by Israel's bombing of Gaza Strip, Hamas claims

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas armed wing Al-Qassam Brigades said on Friday that it launched 150 rockets towards the city of Ashkelon in Israel "in response to the displacement and targeting of civilians." The Israel Defense Force says rocket sirens are sounding in Southern Israel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas armed wing says it launched 150 rockets at Israel

children.content: Hamas armed wing Al-Qassam Brigades said on Friday that it launched 150 rockets towards the city of Ashkelon in Israel "in response to the displacement and targeting of civilians."
The Israel Defense Force says rocket sirens are sounding in Southern Israel.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC understands a Qantas flight has left London for Tel Aviv to repatriate Australians stranded in Israel. The first Australian assisted flight is scheduled to depart from Tel Aviv to London in the coming hours, carrying 220 passengers. Global affairs editor John Lyons has just spoken on News Channel about the plans forAustralians who want to get out and return home. "I'm here at Ben-Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv, where in a few hours time 220 Australians are going to turn up for the first of the assisted flights out of Israel," he said. "These flights are operated by Qantas and are free to Australian citizens who want to flee this war zone. But those people lucky enough to get on these flights are certainly more fortunate than the 1 million or so people who live in Gaza City. "The Israeli army has given them 24 hours to evacuate, to move to the south of the Gaza Strip in a clear sign that a ground invasion is imminent. For the elderly, the frail, the disabled, those unable to leave quickly, they could be facing the full wrath of the most powerful army in the Middle East."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian assisted flight leaves London for Tel Aviv

children.content: The ABC understands a Qantas flight has left London for Tel Aviv to repatriate Australians stranded in Israel.
The first Australian assisted flight is scheduled to depart from Tel Aviv to London in the coming hours, carrying 220 passengers.
has just spoken on News Channel about the plans forAustralians who want to get out and return home.
"I'm here at Ben-Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv, where in a few hours time 220 Australians are going to turn up for the first of the assisted flights out of Israel," he said.

"These flights are operated by Qantas and are free to Australian citizens who want to flee this war zone. But those people lucky enough to get on these flights are certainly more fortunate than the 1 million or so people who live in Gaza City.

"The Israeli army has given them 24 hours to evacuate, to move to the south of the Gaza Strip in a clear sign that a ground invasion is imminent. For the elderly, the frail, the disabled, those unable to leave quickly, they could be facing the full wrath of the most powerful army in the Middle East."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas says Israel’s heavy bombardment of the Gaza Strip has killed 13 hostages, including foreigners, held by the group. Hamas said in a statement on Friday that the 13 were killed in various locations over the past 24 hours. It did not give the nationality of the foreigners. There has been no confirmation from Israel. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas says Israel’s heavy bombardment of the Gaza Strip has killed 13 hostages

children.content: Hamas says Israel’s heavy bombardment of the Gaza Strip has killed 13 hostages, including foreigners, held by the group.
Hamas said in a statement on Friday that the 13 were killed in various locations over the past 24 hours.
It did not give the nationality of the foreigners. There has been no confirmation from Israel.

image.altText: The outside of the Toowoomba Court

items.synopsis: The identity of a high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain a secret for now despite a court today denying the man a non-publication order.

title.children: Identity of high-profile man accused of rape in Toowoomba will remain secret

image.altText: A dinner setting in front of Uluru at dusk

items.synopsis: Two senior business executives have appeared in court, accused of an embezzlement scheme against luxury tourism company Voyages that went undetected for months.

title.children: Business executives accused of defrauding Indigenous tourism company of almost $500,000

image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

items.synopsis: As an Aboriginal person, it feels impossible to digest the freight train of messages coming towards us each day. Most of it is about us, without us, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: The Voice debate has put the worst of Australia on display. Indigenous people deserve better

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi wears a black jacket and pants and brown top and holds a black bag as she walks behind a white car.

items.synopsis: Australian singer-songwriter Vanessa Amorosi has denied deliberately making a false statement to authorities, having a bad memory, and trying to win a legal case against her mother because she was short of money.

title.children: 'You guys are … disgusting': Emails between Vanessa Amorosi and her mother shown to court during civil trial

image.altText: a senior police man standing outdoors and talking to the media

items.synopsis: Police will be able to search protesters and require identification ahead of a planned pro-Palestinian rally in Sydney's CBD.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian protestors say 'draconian' police powers won't stop Sydney rally

image.altText: A man sits leaning against a wall, looking wistfully past camera

items.synopsis: When Israeli air strikes began near their home, Hana' Nayem and her family decided to flee on foot. She and more than 20 relatives have taken shelter elsewhere, but right now, nowhere in Gaza is safe.

title.children: No power, no food, and no end in sight: This is life for millions of Palestinians trapped inside Gaza

items.synopsis: Catch up on the day's updates from our coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

image.altText: A woman in glasses staring at a large map.

image.altText: A smiling woman on a beach.

image.altText: Meg Southcombe on The Drum panel.

items.synopsis: In a 56-second clip, student teacher and mental health advocate Meg Southcombe sums up why educators need more respect. Her words are resonating across the internet.

title.children: 'I'll yell it louder for the people at the back': Meg called for more respect for teachers. Her words have struck a nerve

image.altText: Two women standing and smiling.

items.synopsis: Cheng Lei has been used as a political pawn in a broader strategic and diplomatic dance and was released because Beijing saw it as a useful move, writes foreign affairs reporter Stephen Dziedzic.

title.children: Why did Beijing choose this moment to release Cheng Lei, and what might it signify?

image.altText: A hand placing a ballot in a voting box.

items.synopsis: As the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum nears, misinformation about the voting process has intensified. Here are some of the biggest debunked claims.

title.children: Don't do this to your ballot paper if you want your vote to count in the referendum

image.altText: Thick black and grey smoke rises above multistorey buildings following an airstrike.

items.synopsis: Fears are widening that the Israel-Gaza conflict could spread further and create more volatility for investors and the global economy, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

image.altText: Three women from country band The Chicks stand at an open window in front of an ATM.

items.synopsis: Camp Cope, Fanny Lumsden, Freya Josephine Hollick and Tami Neilson explain why there may be no stronger band than the Texan country trio formerly known as The Dixie Chicks.

title.children: Why The Chicks might be the fiercest band in the world

image.altText: A Japanese male rugby union player with his arm around his coach as they celebrate a Rugby World Cup win in 2015.

items.synopsis: Eddie Jones is reportedly set to leave his role as Wallabies coach just nine months after taking the job, with the ABC confirming he is in the running for a return to Japan.

title.children: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones to interview for Japan job as reports swirl about early Australian exit

image.altText: A screenshot of Australia batter Marcus Stoinis's review of a caught behind decision during the Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: The dismissal of Marcus Stoinis likely had little impact on Australia's 134-run loss to South Africa at the World Cup, but Marnus Labuschagne is hoping for some clarity to avoid similar confusion going forward.

title.children: 'The umpires didn't know what was going on': DRS confusion reigns in Australia's World Cup thumping

image.altText: Composite image of Jade Gresham, Xavier Duursma and Shane McAdam.

items.synopsis: Jade Gresham's move to Essendon is competed hours before the free agency deadline, while Jack Gunston shocks Brisbane by requesting a move back to Hawthorn.

title.children: Bombers land big free agency fish, triple-premiership forward requests trade to Hawks

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates, it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". See how the day unfolded on our markets and economics blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears — as it happened

image.altText: A huge plume of toxic smoke rises into the clear sky above an outback road.

items.synopsis: A two-kilometre exclusion zone around the crash site of the chemical truck blaze and triple fatality has been lifted, allowing investigators to begin closer inspection.

title.children: Police investigators access deadly Pilbara chemical truck crash site following explosion risk

image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: Aerial view of large plumes of smoke coming from trees

title.children: Carnarvon National Park closed for further two weeks, as bushfire burns 31,000 hectares of country

title.children: 'I've paid my dues': Cameron Bancroft distances himself from sandpaper ball-tampering saga

image.altText: A boxer clad in white smiles as a man puts his hand on his shoulder.

title.children: Israel prepares for 'ground manoeuvre' against Hamas as Blinken urges restraint

image.altText: A mid shot of a woman holding a small baby with her hand on the shoulder of a small child. They's standing in a park.

items.synopsis: With a shortage of midwives forcing birthing services at a rural hospital to be shuttered for over three months, mothers who were forced to travel hours away from home have spoken about their "frustrating" and "traumatic" journey.

title.children: Pregnant women 'just making it' to nearest hospital after sudden closure of rural birthing service
